title: 103_hr1134
content:
The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" authorizes the transfer of approximately 14,000 acres of public lands to the Secretary of Agriculture, the State of Colorado, and certain political subdivisions without new surveys. The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" transfers about 3,400 acres of public lands to the Secretary of Agriculture for administration as part of the Arapaho National Forest. The boundaries of the forest are modified accordingly, with no impact on existing rights. The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" transfers land to the Secretary of Agriculture for the Arapaho National Forest. Existing rights are preserved, and the Forest Service will administer any authorizations in accordance with applicable laws. Land transfers to the State of Colorado and Clear Creek County are subject to valid existing rights. The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" transfers approximately 3,200 acres of public lands to various entities in Colorado, including towns and the State. The lands will be managed according to a cooperative agreement. The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" transfers 3,200 acres of public lands to entities in Colorado under a cooperative management agreement. The agreement includes stipulations for artifact preservation and land use approval by the Secretary. The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" allows the transfer of public lands to qualified grantees under certain conditions. If the grantee attempts to transfer title or uses the land inconsistently, they must pay the fair market value to the Secretary of the Interior. The "Clear Creek County, Colorado, Public Lands Transfer Act of 1993" allows the transfer of public lands to qualified grantees. If the grantee attempts to transfer title or uses the land inconsistently, they must pay the fair market value to the Secretary of the Interior for management of the public lands. SEC. 5. LAND TRANSFER TO CLEAR CREEK COUNTY, COLORADO. The Secretary shall transfer all right, title, and interest of the United States in approximately 7,400 acres of public lands to Clear Creek County, Colorado. The transfer is subject to the county adopting comprehensive land use plans and zoning regulations. The Secretary will transfer 7,400 acres of public lands to Clear Creek County, Colorado, subject to the county adopting land use plans and regulations consistent with proper management of adjacent lands owned by the United States. An agreement must be reached between the Secretary and the County regarding steps to ensure fair market value sales of the lands, with the County providing annual accountings and making a payment to the United States after 10 years or an earlier date. The County will pay the United States an amount determined by the Secretary, equal to the County's net receipts from selling lands. The Secretary allows the County to deduct necessary costs from gross receipts, including surveying, mapping, preservation, and overhead expenses. The County may transfer unsold lands to another entity. The County can transfer lands to a qualified grantee under the Recreation and Public Purposes Act. Any transferred lands will be held under the same terms and conditions as if transferred by the United States. Lands remaining in County ownership after 10 years will be retained by the County under similar terms. The Recreation and Public Purposes Act terms and conditions also apply to the mineral estate in the lands. SEC. 6. MINERALS. Withdrawal From Mineral Entry: The public lands in sections 4 and 5 are withdrawn from mining and leasing laws, not open to mining claims or leases, and not available for disposal of mineral materials. No patents will be issued for mining claims after the enactment of this Act. "Act for any mining or mill site claim located under the general mining laws within the public lands referred to in sections 4 and 5." SEC. 7. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. (a) Inspections. The Secretary or any officer of the United States is not required to inspect the public lands described in this Act for hazardous substances. 
(b) Liability. The United States is not responsible for hazardous wastes placed on the lands after transfer to another party. 
(c) Accounting. Receipts distribution is specified in the Act. For accounting purposes, funds paid by the County to the United States under an agreement are considered receipts from the sale of public lands and must be accounted for in documents for Bureau of Land Management appropriations. The curr_chunk is about the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States, who also serves as the President of the Senate.
